Enum Constant Detail

IRC_PING

public static final Event IRC_PING
This event is triggered when the server sends us a PING command, or someone else does. This is handled in the IRCBase.handleInternalEvent(Event, EventArgs) method, but it can also be handled in the IRCBase.handleEvent(Event, EventArgs) method without impairing normal functionality.

Params (gotten with EventArgs.getParam(String)):
server -- The server we're recieving a ping from (may also be a nickname, not sure though.)

IRC_PRIVMSG

public static final Event IRC_PRIVMSG
This event is triggered when a user sends a PRIVMSG to us or a channel we are in. This is a normal event, and is not handled by IRCBase.handleInternalEvent(Event, EventArgs).

Params (gotten with EventArgs.getParam(String)):
from -- The person who sent the PRIVMSG.
from-host -- The host of the person sending the PRIVMSG.
to -- The nickname/channel the PRIVMSG is being sent to. If it is a message only to us, to will equal IRCBase.getNick()
message -- The actual message.

IRC_JOIN_TOPIC

public static final Event IRC_JOIN_TOPIC
This event is triggered when we join and are notified of the topic. This is handled in the IRCBase.handleInternalEvent(Event, EventArgs) method, but it can also be handled in the IRCBase.handleEvent(Event, EventArgs) method without impairing the normal functionality.

Params (gotten with EventArgs.getParam(String)):
server -- The server that told us about it.
channel -- The channel we were told about.
topic -- The actual topic.

IRC_TOPIC

public static final Event IRC_TOPIC
This event is triggered when we get notified that the topic has changed. This is handled in the IRCBase.handleInternalEvent(Event, EventArgs) method, but it can also be handled in the IRCBase.handleEvent(Event, EventArgs) method without impairing normal functionality.

Params (gotten with EventArgs.getParam(String)):
setter -- The nick of the person setting the topic.
setter-host -- The hostname of the person setting the topic.
channel -- The channel the topic was set on.
topic -- The text of the topic.

IRC_RESPONSE_CODE

public static final Event IRC_RESPONSE_CODE
This event is triggered when we get sent any IRC response code. This may be any of the things in IRCConstants. This is not handled by IRCBase.handleInternalEvent(Event, EventArgs) method.

Params (gotten with EventArgs.getParam(String)):
code: The numeric representation of the sent code. Matches with a value in the IRCConstants class. This is of type Integer.
text: The text of the response.
server: The server sending the code.

IRC_JOIN

public static final Event IRC_JOIN
This event is triggered when a user joins a channel we are in. This is not handled in IRCBase.handleInternalEvent(Event, EventArgs).

Params (gotten with EventArgs.getParam(String):
nick -- The nick of the user joining the channel.
host -- The hostname of the user joining the channel.
channel -- The channel the user is joining.

IRC_PART

public static final Event IRC_PART
This event is triggered when a user leaves a channel we are in. This is not handled in IRCBase.handleInternalEvent(Event, EventArgs).

Params (gotten with EventArgs.getParam(String):
nick -- The nick of the user leaving the channel
host -- The hostname of the user leaving the channel.
channel -- The channel being left
message -- The part message of the user when leaving the channel. Generally, servers fill this in if it is not provided, but it is possible that it may send a PART without a message. In that case, the message parameter will be null.

IRC_KICK

public static final Event IRC_KICK
This event is triggered when a user (possibly us) is kicked from a channel we are in. This is not handled in IRCBase.handleInternalEvent(Event, EventArgs).

Params (gotten with EventArgs.getParam(String)):
kicker -- The nick of the person kicking the user from the channel.
kicker-host -- The hostname of the person kicking the user from the channel.
channel -- The channel the user is being kicked from.
kicked -- The nick of the user being kicked.

Possible bugs in this event:
- This event may not provide completely correct information if the command uses the comma- separated list syntax in this command. I have never seen a server do it, and I'm still attempting to think of a way to implement it. If you see a server that uses this syntax for it's kicks, please send me a email or tell me on IRC with the name and version of the server software sending the command to your client. (You can obtain this information through the use of a VERSION command on the server. You really only need the first line of this response. It should look something like "Unreal3.2.8-gs.9. Rubicon.GeekShed.net :FhiXeOoEmM3 [*=2309").

IRC_NICK_CHANGE

public static final Event IRC_NICK_CHANGE
This event is triggered when a user changes their nick on a channel we are in. The bot cannot provide channel information for this event, as it is only triggered once, no matter how many channels we have in common with the user. This is not handled in the IRCBase.handleInternalEvent(Event, EventArgs) method. This may change in another version though.

Params (gotten with EventArgs.getParam(String):
nick-old -- The old nick of the user, before this event.
nick-new -- The new nick of the user, after this event.
host -- The hostname of the user changing their nick.

IRC_NOTICE

public static final Event IRC_NOTICE
This event is triggered when someone sends a notice to us or a channel we are in. This event functions almost exactly as the IRC_PRIVMSG event, but I will explain it's params here. This is not handled in the IRCBase.handleInternalEvent(Event, EventArgs) method.

Params (gotten with EventArgs.getParam(String)):
from -- The nick of the user sending the message.
from-host -- The hostname of the user sending the message.
to -- The nick of the user/channel this message is being sent to. This parameter will be the bot's nick if the message is directed to us only.
message -- The body of the message being sent to us.

IRC_QUIT

public static final Event IRC_QUIT
This event is triggered when someone quits in a channel we are in. The bot cannot provide channel information on this event because it is only sent to us once, no matter how many channels we have in common with the user. This event is not handled in the IRCBase.handleInternalEvent(Event, EventArgs) method. This may change if a further feature requires that we keep a constantly updated list of users in all channels we are in.

Params (gotten with EventArgs.getParam(String)):
nick -- The nick of the user quitting.
host -- The hostname of the user quitting.
message -- The quit message specified. As with the IRC_PART event, this parameter may be null.
This is because the server is not required to send a message along with the command (although it generally fills it in with something). The protocol does specify, however, that if servers detect that the connection was closed unexpectedly (the client did not send a QUIT message) then it must fill in the quit message with something appropriately describing the circumstances.

IRC_MODE

public static final Event IRC_MODE
This event is triggered when a user or a server sets a mode on us or a channel we are in. I was going to implement the ability for events describing certain modes (a set moderated event, etc.) but that would add more to the size of the finished JAR (by added in extra checks, and documentation (docs only affecting the source packages). If you believe that it is worth it, I may add another "non-lightweight" version containing more events for simplifying the handling of others.) This event is not handled in the IRCBase.handleInternalEvent(Event, EventArgs) method.

Params (gotten with EventArgs.getParam(String)):
setter -- The person (or server) setting the mode.
setter-host -- If a user is setting the mode, then this is the host of the person setting the mode. If it is a server, then it is also the name of the server (copied from the "setter" parameter).
mode -- The actual String of + and - modes.
mode-params -- The list of parameters to the mode. This may be null if no parameters are specified in the command.

IRC_UNKNOWN

public static final Event IRC_UNKNOWN
This event is triggered when a line that the bot does not understand is sent to it. For example a non-standard statement or a part of the protocol I (embarrassingly) forgot to implement. This event is (obviously?) not handled in the IRCBase.handleInternalEvent(Event, EventArgs) method.

Params (gotten with EventArgs.getParam(String)):
line -- The raw line received from the server.

IRC_NICKINUSE

public static final Event IRC_NICKINUSE
This event is used in the bot as a method to get passed the limitation of not being able to retrieve Strings from the Socket's buffer except for in the IRCReceiver class. Currently, this event is never sent to IRCEventListeners other than IRCBase.handleInternalEvent(Event, EventArgs), as the handling of it in IRCBase.handleInternalEvent(Event, EventArgs) involves the application exiting. This may later be revised to allow bots to execute cleanup code when our nick is already in use.

Params (gotten with EventArgs.getParam(String)):
line -- The raw line received from the server. Currently not used.
